<center><h1><font size="6"> Anna (Ganna) Malinovskaya</h1></font> </center>
<br>
<center>
<font size="4"> Ph.D. Candidate in <a href="https://dyson.cornell.edu/" style="color: #8B0000; text-decoration: underline;">Applied Economics & Management</a> at the SC Johnson College of Business, Cornell University </font> 

<font size="3"> <a href="https://namedrop.io/annamalinovskaya" style="color: #8B0000; text-decoration: underline;">Pronouncing my name</a> </font>   

<font size="2"> My fields of specialization are Public Economics and Applied Microeconomics, with interests in Labor Economics and Health Equity. I am particularly interested in using microdata and robust quasi-experimental research designs to study how public policy in the US, especially _health_ policy, can better serve low-income and marginalized populations, and how _interactions_ among public policies can help facilitate human capital accumulation for such populations.</font> 

<font size="2"> In my job market paper, I am using multiple quasi-experimental research designs to study not only whether the effects of exposure to a large-scale public program (WIC) in childhood persist through adulthood, but also whether exposure to _multiple_ public programs, even from different domains can lead to policy multiplier effects.

My research has been funded by the <a href="https://www.russellsage.org/awarded-project/covid-driven-technology-adoption-and-worker-inequality-us" style="color: #8B0000; text-decoration: underline;">Russell Sage Foundation</a> and the   
<a href="https://equitablegrowth.org/people/anna-malinovskaya/" style="color: #8B0000; text-decoration: underline;">DC Center for Equitable Growth</a>.</font>
</center>
<br>
